My heart was no lesse cut with Care then his</br>Because he staid not to heare my excuse,</br>I know he deem'd I willing did amisse,</br>Which did more sorrow in my soule infuse:</br>Taking no leave, He faire Vienna leaves,</br>Accompany'd with Care-increasing griefes.

All-woe-begone, He wanders here and there,</br>Lookes most for rest when furthest from resort,</br>Submits himselfe soley to sad Despaire,</br>With cheering-comfort He cannot comport:</br>At last He came unto an obscure shade,</br>Where mirthlesse Melancholy mansion had.

Low on the ground grew Isope, Wormewood, Rew,</br>The mourning mouting trees white Cypresse green,</br>Whose twining tops so close together grew,</br>They all seem'd as they but one Bow had beene;</br>Covering a spacious Tombe where cursed Care</br>Her selfe had sepulchriz'd with dire Despaire.

No wanton Bird there warbled loving layes,</br>There was no merry Merle, Gold-Finch, or Thrush;</br>No other hopping Bird in higher sprayes,</br>No mourning Nightengale in lower bush:</br>The carcasse-craving-Raven, Night-Crow, Owle,</br>In this darke grove their hatefull notes did howle.

This sullen seat doth sute well with his soule,</br>There throwes himselfe downe in the bitter weeds;</br>His heart did thrust out sighs, his tongue condole,</br>His watring eyes with bitter moisture feeds</br>These haplesse herbes, there 'gins he to lament,</br>With interrupting sighs his woes to vent.</br>
